resources.string: "White spot disease is caused by a virus named White spot syndrome virus, belonging to the family Nimaviridae and genus Whispovirus. The nomenclature was approved by the International Committee on Taxonomy of Viruses (ICTV) under deposit whose name is White spot syndrome virus."

"The infection can cause disease or not, depending on factors still poorly understood, but related to species tolerance and environmental factors. White spots embedded within the exoskeleton are the most commonly observed clinical sign, however, other diseases can cause similar white spots on the shrimp exoskeleton. High levels of color variation, predominantly reddish or pinkish discolored shrimp are seen in sick populations."
"Behavioral changes are signs that should be carefully observed, as a high mortality rate in the population can be expected."
"If the color changes to pink or reddish-brown"
"If animals gather around the edges of crops on the water surface"
"If there is a rapid reduction in food consumption"

"General management practices are the best measures for white spot virus prevention. Avoid high densities in cold seasons. Prefer to use specific pathogen free (SPF) animals or populate with PCR-negative animals. For using biosecurity water and polyculture systems with shrimp and fish."
"Infectious myonecrosis virus (IMNV) is a member of the Totiviridae family."

"In the acute stage of the disease, the animal presents extensive areas of white necrosis in muscles, it is possible to notice the loss of transparency in the region of the tail, which may appear necrotic and reddish in some prawns. Severely affected animals become moribund and mortality can be high and sudden after a stress event."

"Prefer to use tested and negative animals for IMNV through the reverse polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) technique. Prefer to use specific pathogen free (SPF) animals. If there is infection, empty the OIE and MAPA recommendations. Using resistant strains of shrimp is also a good alternative for prevention to IMNV."
"Recently the International Committee on Taxonomy of Viruses (ICTV) classified this virus within the family Parvoviridae, genus Brevidensovirus, species Penaeus stylirostris densovirus (PstDNV)."

"The most obvious chronic clinical sign caused by this virus is a deformed rostrum of shrimp and organisms with smaller size (runt), which has been named as Runt and Deformity Syndrome (RDS). In some cases high mortalities are frequent."

"Pre - screening of IHHNV by PCR to rule out virus infection before populating tanks and nurseries. Good management practices. Animals free of specific disease may be a measure, but is not the most effective action in this case."
"More information about Hipodermal and Hematopoietic Necrosis:"
"Necrotizing hepatopancreatitis is a bacterial disease caused by a gram-negative, Rickettsia-like bacterium that attacks the hepatopancreas."

"Clinical signs include: lethargy, reduced food intake, atrophied and pale hepatopancreas, anorexia, empty digestive tract, low feed conversion, reduced growth softened exoskeleton, flaccid body, loose cuticle, darkened gills, lesions, and ulcerative cuticle."

"According to the OIE, the best treatment for NHP is the use of antibiotics (oxytetracycline and 50% florfenicol) if the disease is detected early. It's important to detect early to avoid cannibalism and start treatment quickly. Using hydrated lime to treat bottoms of tanks reduces the incidence of NHP. Prolonged drying in the sun at the bottom of the nurseries, disinfection of equipment with calcium hypochlorite are important preventive measures. Pathogen-free animal use (SPF) is an effective preventative measure."

"The objective of AquaHealth is to bring improvements to world aquaculture through the availability of information about aquatic animal health in an agile and easy to understand way. With the development of the application, scientific information that was distributed in English and different internet sites is now available easily and offline to producers and other interested parties."

"Biosecurity describes measures to be taken in animal husbandry to avoid the triggering of contagious diseases in the production, contamination of the crop can lead to high animal mortality and harm to the producer. Aquaculture, biosecurity is all about creating barriers that prevent the entry of diseases that contaminate fish or shrimp. Prevention is the most important measure in combating contagious diseases."

"Entry of sanitized vehicles and only one origin"

"• Vehicles providing shrimp transport services must be registered with a disinfection report and come from a single source without having passed through other farms. This measure prevents the introduction or dissemination of pathogens in cultivation."
"Control of pests and entry of wild and domestic animals on farms"
"• Shrimp farms should have an Integrated Pest Control System (CIP) and a protection system to minimize the entry and residence of domestic and wild animals in the farm 's production area."
"It uses post-larvae free of diseases or with health certificate"

"• From the sanitation point of view, the purchase of animals free of pathogens or sanitary certification is the most important aspect for the beginning of the production process in the nurseries. Ideal in the acquisition, collect samples of 100 PL's in triplicate, fix in 95% ethyl alcohol and keep them filed for confirmatory PCR analyzes in case of suspected outbreaks."
"The animals are transported according to the standards and care required during the marketing"
"• Transportation of animals must be carried out in hygienized and proper containers, at appropriate temperature and with GTA, when applicable."
"Expenditure involves care such as personal hygiene and use of PPE from the personnel involved, as well as hygiene of equipment involved"

"• The farm must comply with the biosafety regulations regarding the personnel involved in the operations. Equipment should be sanitized after use by spraying with the use of 100 ppm chlorinated solution."
"Balanced feeding by analyzing the amount of feed and the nutritional requirements according to the life stage"
"• Providing a balanced diet is important for the production of healthy animals and for the development of the immune system of animals."
"Conducts treatment to reduce soil organic matter in nurseries"

"• Organic matter may originate from plankton, organic fertilizers, remains of unconsumed feed and feces from shrimp and other animals present in the growing environment. One way to treat organic matter is the continuous and systematic use of probiotics. Avoiding dead spots inside the tanks with the adjustment of the aerators as well as the use of probiotics aid in the treatment of organic matter."
"Performs monitoring and treatment of nursery water"
"• Monitoring, control and treatment of water is a mandatory practice on farms. The tolerable limits of the main water quality parameters should be observed."
"The people involved in the production process were sufficiently trained for their functions"
"• Personnel involved in the activities of the shrimp farm should use specific PPE and receive training and updates for their functions."
"Cleaning and sanitation is carried out on premises and after"
"• Cleaning and sanitizing must be carried out on site and always after an expense. Performed by trained personnel and using appropriate Personal Protective Equipment (PPE)."
